channel.title: Articles by John Graham on Tech Terminologies
channel.description: Recent content in Articles by John Graham on Tech Terminologies

item.title: What is CDFS (Compact Disc File System)?
item.description: The Compact Disc File System, also known as CDFS, is a file system used to store and access data on a compact disc.

item.title: What is Document Grinding?
item.description: Document grinding, also known as document shredding or document destruction, is the process of securely destroying physical documents to protect sensitive information from being accessed by unauthorized parties.

item.title: What is a Vector File Format (Vector Graphics)?
item.description: Vector graphics are a type of digital image that are created using mathematical algorithms rather than pixels.

item.title: What is a Command-Line Installer?
item.description: A command-line installer is a type of software that installs programs or files onto a computer through the use of commands entered into a command-line interface (CLI).

item.title: What is a DLC (Downloadable Content)?
item.description: A DLC, or downloadable content, is additional content that can be downloaded and added to a video game after its initial release.

item.title: What is a Zone File?
item.description: A zone file is a configuration file that is used to define the DNS (Domain Name System) information for a particular domain.

item.title: What is Email?
item.description: Email, or electronic mail, is a method of exchanging digital messages between computers.

item.title: What is the Address Bar?
item.description: The address bar, also known as the URL bar or location bar, is a feature found in most web browsers that allows users to input and navigate to a specific webpage.

item.title: What is NBA (Network Behavior Analysis)?
item.description: Network behavior analysis is a cybersecurity technique that involves the continuous monitoring and analysis of network traffic and activity to identify unusual or malicious behavior.

item.title: What is Network Topology?
item.description: Network topology refers to the layout or structure of a network.

item.title: What is Latency?
item.description: Latency is the time it takes for a signal or a request to be transmitted and received by a system.

item.title: What is a Factory Reset?
item.description: A factory reset, also known as a hard reset or master reset, is the process of restoring a device to its original manufacturer settings.

item.title: What is CGI (Computer-generated Imagery)?
item.description: Computer-generated imagery (CGI) is a technique used to create digital images or animations using computer software.

item.title: What is APU (Accelerated Processing Unit)?
item.description: An APU, or accelerated processing unit, is a type of processor that combines a CPU and GPU on a single chip.

item.title: What is a Wireless Adapter?
item.description: A wireless adapter is a device that connects to a computer or other device and allows it to communicate over a wireless network.

item.title: What is Active-Matrix Liquid Crystal Display (AMLCD)
item.description: An Active-Matrix Liquid Crystal Display (AMLCD) is a type of liquid crystal display (LCD) that is used in many electronic devices, such as laptops, televisions, and smartphones.

item.title: What is an Access Point (AP)?
item.description: An access point (AP) is a device that allows wireless devices to connect to a network using Wi-Fi or a similar wireless technology.

item.title: What is a Memory Address?
item.description: A memory address is a unique identifier for a specific location in a computer’s memory.

item.title: What is Cloud Waste?
item.description: Cloud waste refers to the inefficient use of resources, such as computing power and storage, in cloud computing environments.

item.title: What is ActiveX?
item.description: ActiveX is a technology developed by Microsoft that is used to create software components that can be used in a variety of applications and programming languages.
